    3551                 :            : 
    3552                 :            :         // If a tx has been detected by m_recent_rejects, we will have reached
    3553                 :            :         // this point and the tx will have been ignored. Because we haven't
    3554                 :            :         // submitted the tx to our mempool, we won't have computed a DoS
    3555                 :            :         // score for it or determined exactly why we consider it invalid.
    3556                 :            :         //
    3557                 :            :         // This means we won't penalize any peer subsequently relaying a DoSy
    3558                 :            :         // tx (even if we penalized the first peer who gave it to us) because
    3559                 :            :         // we have to account for m_recent_rejects showing false positives. In
    3560                 :            :         // other words, we shouldn't penalize a peer if we aren't *sure* they
    3561                 :            :         // submitted a DoSy tx.
    3562                 :            :         //
    3563                 :            :         // Note that m_recent_rejects doesn't just record DoSy or invalid
    3564                 :            :         // transactions, but any tx not accepted by the mempool, which may be
    3565                 :            :         // due to node policy (vs. consensus). So we can't blanket penalize a
    3566                 :            :         // peer simply for relaying a tx that our m_recent_rejects has caught,
    3567                 :            :         // regardless of false positives.
    3568                 :            :

    3755                 :            :             // will be detected and the peer will be disconnected/discouraged.

             #  #  #  # ]
    3765                 :          0 :             }
    3766                 :            :             // Setting force_processing to true means that we bypass some of
    3767                 :            :             // our anti-DoS protections in AcceptBlock, which filters
    3768                 :            :             // unrequested blocks that might be trying to waste our resources
    3769                 :            :             // (eg disk space). Because we only try to reconstruct blocks when
    3770                 :            :             // we're close to caught up (via the CanDirectFetch() requirement
    3771                 :            :             // above, combined with the behavior of not requesting blocks until
    3772                 :            :             // we have a chain with at least nMinimumChainWork), and we ignore

    3824                 :            :                 // READ_STATUS_CHECKBLOCK_FAILED.

    3826                 :            :                 // 1. bad-proof-of-work (impossible here, because we've already
    3827                 :            :                 //    accepted the header)
    3828                 :            :                 // 2. merkleroot doesn't match the transactions given (already
    3829                 :            :                 //    caught in FillBlock with READ_STATUS_FAILED, so
    3830                 :            :                 //    impossible here)
    3831                 :            :                 // 3. the block is otherwise invalid (eg invalid coinbase,
    3832                 :            :                 //    block is too big, too many legacy sigops, etc).
    3833                 :            :                 // So if CheckBlock failed, #3 is the only possibility.
    3834                 :            :                 // Under BIP 152, we don't discourage the peer unless proof of work is
    3835                 :            :                 // invalid (we don't require all the stateless checks to have
    3836                 :            :                 // been run).  This is handled below, so just treat this as
    3837                 :            :                 // though the block was successfully read, and rely on the
    3838                 :            :                 // handling in ProcessNewBlock to ensure the block index is
    3839                 :            :                 // updated, etc.

    3843                 :            :                 // updating which peers send us compact blocks, so the race
    3844                 :            :                 // between here and cs_main in ProcessNewBlock is fine.
    3845                 :            :                 // BIP 152 permits peers to relay compact blocks after validating
    3846                 :            :                 // the header only; we should not punish peers if the block turns
    3847                 :            :                 // out to be invalid.

    3918   [ #  #  #  # ]:          0 :     if (msg_type == NetMsgType::GETADDR) {
    3919                 :            :         // This asymmetric behavior for inbound and outbound connections was introduced
    3920                 :            :         // to prevent a fingerprinting attack: an attacker can send specific fake addresses
    3921                 :            :         // to users' AddrMan and later request them by sending getaddr messages.
    3922                 :            :         // Making nodes which are behind NAT and can only make outgoing connections ignore
    3923                 :            :         // the getaddr message mitigates the attack.
    3924   [ #  #  #  # ]:          0 :         if (!pfrom.IsInboundConn()) {
    3925   [ #  #  #  #  :          0 :             LogPrint(BCLog::NET, "Ignoring \"getaddr\" from %s connection. peer=%d\n", pfrom.ConnectionTypeAsString(), pfrom.GetId());

    3926                 :          0 :             return;
    3927                 :            :         }
    3928                 :            : 
    3929                 :            :         // Since this must be an inbound connection, SetupAddressRelay will
    3930                 :            :         // never fail.
    3931   [ #  #  #  # ]:          0 :         Assume(SetupAddressRelay(pfrom, *peer));
    3932                 :            : 
    3933                 :            :         // Only send one GetAddr response per connection to reduce resource waste
    3934                 :            :         // and discourage addr stamping of INV announcements.
    3935         [ #  # ]:          0 :         if (peer->m_getaddr_recvd) {
    3936   [ #  #  #  #  :          0 :             LogPrint(BCLog::NET, "Ignoring repeated \"getaddr\". peer=%d\n", pfrom.GetId());

    3937                 :          0 :             return;
    3938                 :            :         }
    3939                 :          0 :         peer->m_getaddr_recvd = true;
    3940                 :            : 
    3941                 :          0 :         peer->m_addrs_to_send.clear();

    3946         [ #  # ]:          0 :             vAddr = m_connman.GetAddresses(pfrom, MAX_ADDR_TO_SEND, MAX_PCT_ADDR_TO_SEND);
    3947                 :            :         }
    3948                 :          0 :         FastRandomContext insecure_rand;
    3949         [ #  # ]:          0 :         for (const CAddress &addr : vAddr) {
    3950         [ #  # ]:          0 :             PushAddress(*peer, addr, insecure_rand);

    3953                 :          0 :     }
    3954                 :            : 
    3955   [ #  #  #  # ]:          0 :     if (msg_type == NetMsgType::MEMPOOL) {

    3982                 :            : 
    3983   [ #  #  #  # ]:          0 :     if (msg_type == NetMsgType::PING) {
    3984   [ #  #  #  # ]:          0 :         if (pfrom.GetCommonVersion() > BIP0031_VERSION) {
    3985                 :          0 :             uint64_t nonce = 0;
    3986         [ #  # ]:          0 :             vRecv >> nonce;
    3987                 :            :             // Echo the message back with the nonce. This allows for two useful features:
    3988                 :            :             //
    3989                 :            :             // 1) A remote node can quickly check if the connection is operational
    3990                 :            :             // 2) Remote nodes can measure the latency of the network thread. If this node
    3991                 :            :             //    is overloaded it won't respond to pings quickly and the remote node can
    3992                 :            :             //    avoid sending us more work, like chain download requests.
    3993                 :            :             //
    3994                 :            :             // The nonce stops the remote getting confused between different pings: without
    3995                 :            :             // it, if the remote node sends a ping once per second and this node takes 5
    3996                 :            :             // seconds to respond to each, the 5th ping the remote sends would appear to
    3997                 :            :             // return very quickly.
    3998   [ #  #  #  #  :          0 :             m_connman.PushMessage(&pfrom, msgMaker.Make(NetMsgType::PONG, nonce));
                   #  # ]
    3999                 :          0 :         }
    4000                 :          0 :         return;
    4001                 :            :     }
    4002                 :            : 
    4003   [ #  #  #  # ]:          0 :     if (msg_type == NetMsgType::PONG) {
    4004                 :          0 :         const auto ping_end = time_received;
    4005                 :          0 :         uint64_t nonce = 0;
    4006         [ #  # ]:          0 :         size_t nAvail = vRecv.in_avail();
    4007                 :          0 :         bool bPingFinished = false;
    4008                 :          0 :         std::string sProblem;
    4009                 :            : 
    4010         [ #  # ]:          0 :         if (nAvail >= sizeof(nonce)) {
    4011         [ #  # ]:          0 :             vRecv >> nonce;
    4012                 :            : 
    4013                 :            :             // Only process pong message if there is an outstanding ping (old ping without nonce should never pong)
    4014         [ #  # ]:          0 :             if (peer->m_ping_nonce_sent != 0) {
    4015         [ #  # ]:          0 :                 if (nonce == peer->m_ping_nonce_sent) {
    4016                 :            :                     // Matching pong received, this ping is no longer outstanding
    4017                 :          0 :                     bPingFinished = true;
    4018         [ #  # ]:          0 :                     const auto ping_time = ping_end - peer->m_ping_start.load();
    4019   [ #  #  #  # ]:          0 :                     if (ping_time.count() >= 0) {
    4020                 :            :                         // Let connman know about this successful ping-pong
    4021         [ #  # ]:          0 :                         pfrom.PongReceived(ping_time);
    4022                 :          0 :                     } else {
    4023                 :            :                         // This should never happen
    4024         [ #  # ]:          0 :                         sProblem = "Timing mishap";
    4025                 :            :                     }
    4026                 :          0 :                 } else {
    4027                 :            :                     // Nonce mismatches are normal when pings are overlapping
    4028         [ #  # ]:          0 :                     sProblem = "Nonce mismatch";
    4029         [ #  # ]:          0 :                     if (nonce == 0) {
    4030                 :            :                         // This is most likely a bug in another implementation somewhere; cancel this ping

    4298                 :          0 : void PeerManagerImpl::ConsiderEviction(CNode& pto, std::chrono::seconds time_in_seconds)
    4299                 :            : {
    4300                 :          0 :     AssertLockHeld(cs_main);
    4301                 :            : 
    4302                 :          0 :     CNodeState &state = *State(pto.GetId());
    4303                 :          0 :     const CNetMsgMaker msgMaker(pto.GetCommonVersion());
    4304                 :            : 
    4305   [ #  #  #  #  :          0 :     if (!state.m_chain_sync.m_protect && pto.IsOutboundOrBlockRelayConn() && state.fSyncStarted) {
                   #  # ]
    4306                 :            :         // This is an outbound peer subject to disconnection if they don't
    4307                 :            :         // announce a block with as much work as the current tip within
    4308                 :            :         // CHAIN_SYNC_TIMEOUT + HEADERS_RESPONSE_TIME seconds (note: if
    4309                 :            :         // their chain has more work than ours, we should sync to it,
    4310                 :            :         // unless it's invalid, in which case we should find that out and
    4311                 :            :         // disconnect from them elsewhere).

    4313         [ #  # ]:          0 :             if (state.m_chain_sync.m_timeout != 0s) {
    4314                 :          0 :                 state.m_chain_sync.m_timeout = 0s;
    4315                 :          0 :                 state.m_chain_sync.m_work_header = nullptr;
    4316                 :          0 :                 state.m_chain_sync.m_sent_getheaders = false;
    4317                 :          0 :             }

    4319                 :            :             // Our best block known by this peer is behind our tip, and we're either noticing
    4320                 :            :             // that for the first time, OR this peer was able to catch up to some earlier point

    4322                 :            :             // Either way, set a new timeout based on current tip.

    4325                 :          0 :             state.m_chain_sync.m_sent_getheaders = false;

    4328                 :            :             // of our tip, when we first detected it was behind. Send a single getheaders

    4331                 :            :                 // They've run out of time to catch up!

    4350                 :            : 
    4351                 :          0 : void PeerManagerImpl::EvictExtraOutboundPeers(std::chrono::seconds now)
    4352                 :            : {
    4353                 :            :     // If we have any extra block-relay-only peers, disconnect the youngest unless
    4354                 :            :     // it's given us a block -- in which case, compare with the second-youngest, and
    4355                 :            :     // out of those two, disconnect the peer who least recently gave us a block.
    4356                 :            :     // The youngest block-relay-only peer would be the extra peer we connected
    4357                 :            :     // to temporarily in order to sync our tip; see net.cpp.
    4358                 :            :     // Note that we use higher nodeid as a measure for most recent connection.
    4359         [ #  # ]:          0 :     if (m_connman.GetExtraBlockRelayCount() > 0) {
    4360                 :          0 :         std::pair<NodeId, std::chrono::seconds> youngest_peer{-1, 0}, next_youngest_peer{-1, 0};
    4361                 :            : 
    4362         [ #  # ]:          0 :         m_connman.ForEachNode([&](CNode* pnode) {
    4363   [ #  #  #  # ]:          0 :             if (!pnode->IsBlockOnlyConn() || pnode->fDisconnect) return;
    4364         [ #  # ]:          0 :             if (pnode->GetId() > youngest_peer.first) {
    4365                 :          0 :                 next_youngest_peer = youngest_peer;
    4366                 :          0 :                 youngest_peer.first = pnode->GetId();
    4367                 :          0 :                 youngest_peer.second = pnode->m_last_block_time;
    4368                 :          0 :             }
    4369                 :          0 :         });
    4370                 :          0 :         NodeId to_disconnect = youngest_peer.first;
    4371         [ #  # ]:          0 :         if (youngest_peer.second > next_youngest_peer.second) {
    4372                 :            :             // Our newest block-relay-only peer gave us a block more recently;
    4373                 :            :             // disconnect our second youngest.
    4374                 :          0 :             to_disconnect = next_youngest_peer.first;
    4375                 :          0 :         }
    4376         [ #  # ]:          0 :         m_connman.ForNode(to_disconnect, [&](CNode* pnode) EXCLUSIVE_LOCKS_REQUIRED(::cs_main) {
    4377                 :          0 :             AssertLockHeld(::cs_main);
    4378                 :            :             // Make sure we're not getting a block right now, and that
    4379                 :            :             // we've been connected long enough for this eviction to happen
    4380                 :            :             // at all.
    4381                 :            :             // Note that we only request blocks from a peer if we learn of a
    4382                 :            :             // valid headers chain with at least as much work as our tip.
    4383                 :          0 :             CNodeState *node_state = State(pnode->GetId());

    4385         [ #  # ]:          0 :                 (now - pnode->m_connected >= MINIMUM_CONNECT_TIME && node_state->nBlocksInFlight == 0)) {

    4394                 :          0 :             return false;
    4395                 :          0 :         });
    4396                 :          0 :     }
    4397                 :            :

    4400                 :            :         // If we have more outbound-full-relay peers than we target, disconnect one.
    4401                 :            :         // Pick the outbound-full-relay peer that least recently announced
    4402                 :            :         // us a new block, with ties broken by choosing the more recent
    4403                 :            :         // connection (higher node id)

    4405                 :          0 :         int64_t oldest_block_announcement = std::numeric_limits<int64_t>::max();
    4406                 :            :

    4426                 :            :                 // Only disconnect a peer that has been connected to us for
    4427                 :            :                 // some reasonable fraction of our check-frequency, to give
    4428                 :            :                 // it time for new information to have arrived.

    4539                 :            :         // once a day on average).

    4592                 :          0 : void PeerManagerImpl::MaybeSendFeefilter(CNode& pto, Peer& peer, std::chrono::microseconds current_time)

    4605         [ #  # ]:          0 :     if (m_chainman.ActiveChainstate().IsInitialBlockDownload()) {
    4606                 :            :         // Received tx-inv messages are discarded when the active
    4607                 :            :         // chainstate is in IBD, so tell the peer to not send them.
    4608                 :          0 :         currentFilter = MAX_MONEY;
    4609                 :          0 :     } else {
    4610   [ #  #  #  #  :          0 :         static const CAmount MAX_FILTER{g_filter_rounder.round(MAX_MONEY)};
                   #  # ]
    4611         [ #  # ]:          0 :         if (peer.m_fee_filter_sent == MAX_FILTER) {
    4612                 :            :             // Send the current filter if we sent MAX_FILTER previously
    4613                 :            :             // and made it out of IBD.
    4614                 :          0 :             peer.m_next_send_feefilter = 0us;
    4615                 :          0 :         }
    4616                 :            :     }
    4617         [ #  # ]:          0 :     if (current_time > peer.m_next_send_feefilter) {
    4618                 :          0 :         CAmount filterToSend = g_filter_rounder.round(currentFilter);
    4619                 :            :         // We always have a fee filter of at least minRelayTxFee
    4620                 :          0 :         filterToSend = std::max(filterToSend, ::minRelayTxFee.GetFeePerK());

    4622   [ #  #  #  #  :          0 :             m_connman.PushMessage(&pto, CNetMsgMaker(pto.GetCommonVersion()).Make(NetMsgType::FEEFILTER, filterToSend));
                   #  # ]
    4623                 :          0 :             peer.m_fee_filter_sent = filterToSend;
    4624                 :          0 :         }
    4625                 :          0 :         peer.m_next_send_feefilter = GetExponentialRand(current_time, AVG_FEEFILTER_BROADCAST_INTERVAL);
    4626                 :          0 :     }
    4627                 :            :     // If the fee filter has changed substantially and it's still more than MAX_FEEFILTER_CHANGE_DELAY
    4628                 :            :     // until scheduled broadcast, then move the broadcast to within MAX_FEEFILTER_CHANGE_DELAY.
    4629   [ #  #  #  # ]:          0 :     else if (current_time + MAX_FEEFILTER_CHANGE_DELAY < peer.m_next_send_feefilter &&

    4633                 :          0 : }

    4731                 :            :             // peers, or if we aren't downloading any blocks from such peers,
    4732                 :            :             // then allow block downloads from this peer, too.
    4733                 :            :             // We prefer downloading blocks from outbound peers to avoid

    4758                 :            :                    best known header.  This ensures that we always get a
    4759                 :            :                    non-empty list of headers back as long as the peer
    4760                 :            :                    is up-to-date.  With a non-empty response, we can initialise
    4761                 :            :                    the peer's known best block.  This wouldn't be possible
    4762                 :            :                    if we requested starting at m_chainman.m_best_header and

    4772                 :            :         // Try sending block announcements via headers

                      # ]
    5057                 :            :             // Stalling only triggers when the block download window cannot move. During normal steady state,
    5058                 :            :             // the download window should be much larger than the to-be-downloaded set of blocks, so disconnection
    5059                 :            :             // should only happen during initial block download.
    5060   [ #  #  #  #  :          0 :             LogPrintf("Peer=%d is stalling block download, disconnecting\n", pto->GetId());
             #  #  #  # ]
    5061                 :          0 :             pto->fDisconnect = true;
    5062                 :          0 :             return true;
    5063                 :            :         }
    5064                 :            :         // In case there is a block that has been in flight from this peer for block_interval * (1 + 0.5 * N)
    5065                 :            :         // (with N the number of peers from which we're downloading validated blocks), disconnect due to timeout.
    5066                 :            :         // We compensate for other peers to prevent killing off peers due to our own downstream link
    5067                 :            :         // being saturated. We only count validated in-flight blocks so peers can't advertise non-existing block hashes
    5068                 :            :         // to unreasonably increase our timeout.
